title: What can you learn from ancient poop?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are difficult to preserve

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not interesting to scientists

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not relevant to human history

multiple-choice.question: What happens to feces when they are preserved in a mummy's desiccated intestines?

options.label: C
options.text: They leave dents in the earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Viking monstrosity discovered in England?
What did the contents of 1-2 millennia-old coprolites in Puerto Rico reveal?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of a single cultural group

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of two distinct cultural groups

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of a single language

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of a single diet

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of death of the Medieval warlord Cangrande della Scala?

options.label: C
options.text: A severe bout of vomiting and diarrhea

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the warlord who died at the age of 38?
What is the name of the poet who was patronized by Cangrande della Scala?
How did the researchers analyze the feces preserved in the corpse's rectum?
What is the main idea of the episode of Gross Science?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of coprolites in human history

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of relevance of coprolites to human history
